awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Collaborative Research: High-performance hybrid micromagnetic-electromagnetic simulators for memory and high-performance data storage devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Data is at the heart of the digital revolution. Changing work habits, increasingly stringent electronic record-keeping mandates, and developments in the health care, energy, and retail sectors all suggest a growing demand for data storage and memories for the foreseeable future. Fast, low-power, ultra-high density, and non-volatile magnetic storage and memory systems are projected to accommodate the bulk of the global data storage needs for decades to come and spawn revolutionary data-intensive computing modalities along the way. Their timely development, however, critically depends on the availability of fast and accurate computational tools capable of simulating electromagnetic field and magnetization dynamics in complete magnetic data storage and memory systems. Unfortunately, current simulators are not up to this task. 
This study focuses on the development of high-performance hybrid micro magnetic-electromagnetic simulators for modeling next-generation magnetic memory and data storage systems. The simulators leverage analytically preconditioned time-domain integral equation methods to solve the Maxwell and Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert-Slonczewski equations, which govern coupled electromagnetic field and magnetization phenomena. To facilitate the analysis of such phenomena in complex systems involving billions of degrees of freedom, the simulators are implemented on massively parallel Central Processing Unit (CPU) and Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) computers. These simulators are used for the design of next generation magnetic random memory devices as well as bit patterned media and heat-assisted magnetic recording storage systems. Such advanced memory and storage systems are to be essential to future high-performance computing systems.

por.por_cntn:
Computational techniques for accurately and efficiently modeling magnetization and electromagnetic field dynamics in systems containing magnetic materials are critically important to a host of real-world applications. Specifically, they govern the behavior of many storage devices.  Our ability to engineer storage media with increased capacity/density, mean time between failure, and lifetime is key to sustaining the big data revolution that is upon us.

Prior to the start of this project, existing computational techniques for modeling storage media either solved Maxwell’s equations (MEs) by accounting for magnetization through idealized constitutive relationships, or solved the non-linear Landau-Lifshitz-Gilbert equation (LLGE) cast in terms of (quasi-) static magnetic fields. These solvers’ failure to accurately account for the complexity of the magnetization’s temporal dynamics and field coupling effects constituted a major obstacle in advancing magnetic material and device technology.

To address deficiencies in computational methods for simulating nonlinear magnetization and electromagnetic field dynamics in complex systems containing magnetic materials, we took a two-prong approach.  First, we developed new full-wave time-domain ME solvers that incorporate dynamic LLGE magnetization models in a self-consistent manner. Next, realizing that the simulation of practical devices oftentimes calls for models involving hundreds of millions of spatial unknowns, we accelerated these solvers via time domain fast multipole methods, and implemented them on parallel and Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) accelerated computers. As the new ME-LLGE solvers are devoid of the approximations and computational restrictions inherent to stand-alone ME or LLGE solvers, they were shown to readily apply to phenomena involving highly coupled and even retarded electromagnetic fields.  Moreover, they execute up to 400x faster than previous solvers when executed on GPUs, and can be mapped onto parallel computing clusters of arbitrary size as the underlying accelerators were proven scalable.

The research supported by this project had important applied mathematical, computer science, engineering, and educational outcomes. (i) On the applied mathematical front, it led to novel low-frequency time domain fast multipole schemes, new time domain volume integral equations, and progress in space-time adaptive time domain integral equation solvers, all key technologies that underlie the new ME-LLGE solvers. (ii) In computer science, the research enabled advances in parallel and GPU-accelerated time domain fast multipole methods. (iii) In the engineering realm, the research provided new opportunities for modeling magnetic devices and systems, including the first time ever analysis of a complete magnetic recording head. (iv)  Finally, in education, the research led to enhancements to undergraduate and graduate courses on computational electromagnetics, and, most importantly, the graduation of three Ph.D. students (two at the University of California at San Diego and one at the University of Michigan) who specialized in the development of fast ME-LLGE solvers. 

The new fast parallel and GPU-accelerated time domain fast multipole kernels can, with minor modifications, be used in other fields including biophysics, chemistry, and astrophysics, which require evaluating fields governed by Columbic, Helmholtz, London, or Van der-Waal's potentials; the methods already have been applied to the analysis of bioelectromagnetic problems. Furthermore, the new ME-LLGE solvers can be hybridized with solvers governing other physical domains to support comprehensive multi-physics (electrical/thermal/mechanical/fluidic) modeling frameworks in support of the design of the mixed-technology integrated circuits that advances in nanotechnology promise to deliver.  Most importantly, perhaps, use of the proposed solvers already will facilitate the development of high performance data storage devices, applications of which are pervasive in modern society.
